page.title: 01Introduction
page.content: The River Stour flows eastwards till it is joined by the Glem and the Chad; then it turns south towards Sudbury. The district enclosed in the angle is the most northerly part of Essex. It is all farmland (with a few small copses), up to about 30 metres above the river level, rising gently from the east but much more steeply in the north. There are three small villages -{Foxearth, Pentlow and Borley}- and a tiny one called{Lyston. Along the river there are three old water-mills, now private houses, one at each village except Foxearth (which lies inland and had a windmill) and a picnic-site on the Suffolk bank. Lyston has a factory, spanning both banks, where they distil 'essential oils'; it is known as The Chemical Works or just The Comicals.
